Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer applied the correct legal standard of proof in assessing the applicant's immigration application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian administrative law principles
Legal_Rule: The standard of proof for permanent residence applications in Canada is balance of probabilities, not beyond a reasonable doubt
Procedural_Issue: Misapplication of the legal standard by the decision maker
Grounds_for_Claim: Material error of law due to incorrect standard of proof
Outcome_on_Merits: Application denied based on incorrect legal standard
Review_Standard: Correctness with respect to legal standard, reasonableness otherwise
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Violation of procedural fairness due to erroneous legal standard
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative law, principles of natural justice
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of application based on overly strict standard of proof
Legal_Rule_Source: Statutory interpretation, case law on standard of proof in immigration matters
Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by a different visa officer
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of original decision and referral for re-assessment
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under the Federal Courts Act
Legal_Provision: Section 71(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 71(1), principles from Dunsmuir v. New Brunswick
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet work experience requirements as per misapplied standard
Applicable_Process: Permanent residence application assessment, followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Balance of probabilities is the required standard in immigration assessments
